Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Imagine spending 23 hours a day and 365 days a year alone and confined to a windowless cell the size of a parking space.

Solitary confinement inflicts profound physical and psychological harm on those who experience it — and now these impacted individuals are making their voices heard.

Join us on Tuesday, June 25 for the release of a groundbreaking new report on solitary confinement from the ACLU of Louisiana, Solitary Watch, and the Jesuit Social Research Institute/Loyola University New Orleans.

Louisiana on Lockdown

A report on the use of solitary confinement in Louisiana state prisons, with testimony from the people who live it.

Tuesday, June 25, 10 â€“ 11:30 a.m.
Loyola University New Orleans
Greenville Hall
7214 St. Charles Avenue
New Orleans, LA

RSVP TODAY

The joint report — Louisiana on Lockdown — details the harrowing stories of those living in solitary confinement and calls for sweeping changes in Louisiana state prisons.

On Tuesday, June 25 come show your support for these reforms and hear from survivors like Albert Woodfox, who spent 43 years in solitary confinement.

The report is based on the largest-ever survey of people living in solitary confinement — because ending this inhumane practice starts by listening to those who have lived it, and those who are enduring it still.

Together, we can spotlight this injustice and take a stand for human dignity for all.

We look forward to seeing you there,

ACLU of Louisiana
